statement.text: Chronic mesenteric ischemia (intestinal angina) results from atherosclerotic stenosis of mesenteric arteries, classically presenting with postprandial abdominal pain (intestinal angina), food fear, and significant weight loss, typically requiring two of three mesenteric vessels to be severely stenosed before symptoms occur due to extensive collateralization.
statement.formal: CMI = Postprandial_Pain + Food_Fear + Weight_Loss + Multi_Vessel_Stenosis + Revascularization_Benefits

explanation.intuition: The intestines need a lot of blood after eating to digest food. If the blood supply arteries are narrowed, eating causes pain - like angina of the heart but in the belly. Patients learn to fear food because eating hurts, so they lose a lot of weight. Unlike the heart, the gut has great backup blood supplies, so you usually need blockages in multiple arteries before symptoms start.
explanation.key_insight: The key clinical pearl: CMI typically requires stenosis of at least 2 of 3 mesenteric vessels (celiac, SMA, IMA) due to excellent collateral networks (meandering mesenteric artery, arc of Riolan, pancreaticoduodenal arcades). Single-vessel disease rarely causes symptoms unless collaterals are compromised. SMA is the most important - treat first.
explanation.technical_details: Pathophysiology: atherosclerotic stenosis at ostia → inability to meet postprandial metabolic demand → mucosal ischemia → pain. Classic triad: (1) postprandial pain (within 30-60 min of eating), (2) food fear/sitophobia (patients eat less to avoid pain), (3) significant weight loss (often >20 lbs). Differential: pancreatic cancer, peptic ulcer, gastroparesis. Diagnosis: mesenteric duplex (fasting PSV: celiac >200, SMA >275 suggests >70% stenosis), CTA/MRA for anatomy. Treatment: SMA revascularization is priority (stent preferred if anatomy suitable, bypass if endovascular fails). Celiac stenting controversial due to MAL compression. Outcomes: symptom relief 85-95%, 5-year patency 50-80% for stent, 80-90% for bypass.

clinical_triad.postprandial_pain: Dull, crampy periumbilical pain 15-60 min after eating, lasting 1-3 hours
clinical_triad.food_fear: Sitophobia - patients eat less to avoid pain

pathophysiology.mechanism: Mesenteric blood flow cannot meet increased postprandial demand
pathophysiology.vessels_involved: Usually 2-3 vessel disease required due to collaterals
pathophysiology.progression: May progress to acute mesenteric ischemia (acute-on-chronic)

diagnosis.clinical_suspicion: High in patients with classic triad and atherosclerotic disease

duplex.postprandial: Normally SMA flow increases 50-100% after meal; blunted in CMI

diagnosis.CTA_MRA: Gold standard for anatomic assessment and planning

endovascular.stenting: First-line for most patients; SMA is priority
endovascular.limitations: Lower long-term patency (50-80% at 5 years), in-stent restenosis

surgical.bypass: Antegrade from supraceliac aorta or retrograde from iliac
surgical.indications: Endovascular failure, hostile anatomy, young patients

treatment.medical: Optimize nutrition, small frequent meals, treat atherosclerotic risk factors

definition.@value: Chronic ischemic syndrome caused by mesenteric artery stenosis, characterized by postprandial pain, food fear, and weight loss, typically requiring multi-vessel disease due to collateral networks.

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic triad of chronic mesenteric ischemia
Understand why multi-vessel disease is usually required
Apply duplex criteria for mesenteric stenosis
clinical_pearls: Classic triad: postprandial pain + food fear + weight loss
Usually need 2 of 3 vessels stenosed due to excellent collaterals
Duplex: SMA PSV >275 and celiac PSV >200 suggest significant stenosis
Bypass has better patency than stenting (80-90% vs 50-80% at 5 years)
May present as acute-on-chronic if thromboses
